Munging Data:


we can remove missing data in this case as there is enough data leftover to work with.



wages_clean <-
  wages %>%

  mutate(
    occrecode = as_factor(occrecode),
    wrkstat = as_factor(wrkstat),
    gender = as_factor(gender),
    educcat = as_factor(educcat),
    maritalcat = as_factor(maritalcat),
    rownames = as_factor(rownames),
    year = as_factor(year)

title: Day 5: Groups
section: Q1: What is the basic distribution of realrinc (the respondant’s base income)?
text:
Q1: What is the basic distribution of realrinc (the respondant’s base income)?

wages_clean %>%
  gf_boxplot(realrinc ~ "Income") %>% # Dummy X-axis "variable"
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 1A: Income has a skewed distribution",
    subtitle = "Many outliers on the high side"
  )










This graph has been plotted on a logarithmic scale (1e+05 = 1 x10^5, 2e+05 = 2x10^5 and so on) as the data spans a wide range of values
FROM THIS GRAPH

Income is a very skewed distribution, as might be expected.
Presence of many higher-side outliers is noted.

title: Day 5: Groups
section: Q2: Is realrinc affected by gender?
text:
Q2: Is realrinc affected by gender?

wages_clean %>%
  gf_boxplot(gender ~ realrinc) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A: Income by Gender")









converting scalenatural log to log base 10. why??


wages_clean %>%
  gf_boxplot(gender ~ log10(realrinc)) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2B: Log(Income) by Gender")









wages_clean %>%
  gf_boxplot(gender ~ realrinc, fill = ~gender) %>%
  gf_refine(scale_x_log10()) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2C: Income filled by Gender, log scale")










FROM THE GRAPHS:

Even when split by gender, realincome presents a skewed set of distributions.
The IQR for males is smaller than the IQR for females. There is less variation in the middle ranges of realrinc for men.
log10 transformation helps to view and understand the regions of low realrinc.
There are outliers on both sides, indicating that there may be many people who make very small amounts of money and large amounts of money in both genders.

title: Day 3: Counts
text:
Today we as a class explored Counts using a data set, taxi, about taxi rides taken in Chicago in 2022. Under the ‘Your Turn’ section of the Counts page, I chose to investigate the fertility data set.



First install packages and call them to the document
Then call the data set and perform glimpse(), inspect() and skim()
If there is anything to be munged, the data is re-organised
Looking at the data, questions are developed that can be answered by comparing variables
Then, plot graphs, compare and analyze them
Lastly revisit the entire process with a new dataset!


.
.

    tip = as_factor(tip),

    dow = as_factor(dow),
    company = as_factor(company),
    hour = as_factor(hour)

color vs fill

title: Day 3: Counts
section: Q2.A: Does the tip depend upon whether the trip is local or not?
text:
Q2.A: Does the tip depend upon whether the trip is local or not?

## using colour = ...
taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    color = ~tip,
    position = "dodge"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A.1: Dodged Bar Chart",
          subtitle = "Using Colour")








.

## Using fill = ...
taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "dodge"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A.2: Dodged Bar Chart",
          subtitle = "Using Fill")








.

## Flipping facets
taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~tip,
    fill = ~local,
    position = "dodge"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2A.3: Dodged Bar Chart",
          subtitle = "Flipping 'local' and 'tip' variables:")








.

## Using stack
taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "stack"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2B.1: Stacked Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Can we spot per group differences in proportions??"
  )








.

## Flipping Facets
taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~tip,
    fill = ~local,
    position = "stack"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2B.2: Stacked Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Flipping 'local' and 'tip' variables:"
  )








.

## Using ratio proportions
taxi_modifiedB %>%
  gf_bar(~local,
    fill = ~tip,
    position = "fill"
  ) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 2C: Filled Bar Chart",
    subtitle = "Comparing using perecentages and ratios"
  )








.
.

Understandings from Graphs:

Plot 2B. 1: People tip more often than not, regardless of if the trip is local or not.
Plot 2B. 2: Majority of those who tip are going on trips that are not local. This may be true, but its not the whole truth.
BECAUSE PERCENTAGS MATTER - THE NUMBER OF TRIPS THAT ARE LOCAL AND NOT LOCAL ARE NOT THE SAME.
Plot 2C: Now we can say for sure that more people tip on trips that are not local.


.
.

Data Dictionary:
I tried finding where the data set originated, but couldn’t really trace anything back. From what I could make sense of it, these are my assumptions:

There 2,54,654 participants that make up this dataset, with no missing entries.



morekids: Those who want more kids, either yes or no
gender1: Gender of the first child
gender2: Gender of the second child
age: age of the participant in years
afam: if the participant identifies as African American, either yes or no
hispanic: if the participant identifies as Hispanic, either yes or no
other: if the participant identifies as another minority, either yes or no
work: the number of hours worked in a week

.
.


Munging Data:

fertility_modified <- fertility%>%
  mutate(
    morekids = as_factor(morekids),
    gender1 = as_factor(gender1),
    gender2 = as_factor(gender2),
    afam = as_factor(afam),
    hispanic = as_factor(hispanic),
    other = as_factor(other),
  )
glimpse(fertility_modified)

Q0: How many participants want more kids?

## Count of those who want more kids
fertility_modified %>% gf_bar(~morekids) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 0.A: Counts of those who want More Kids",
          subtitle = "fill = none")








.

## Propotion of those who want more kids
fertility_modified %>% 
  gf_bar(~morekids,
         fill = ~morekids,
          position = "stack"           ) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 0.B: Proportion of those who want More Kids",
          subtitle = "position = 'fill'")








.

Essentialy I wanted a graph with a single bar, but toggling with ‘position’ doesn’t seem to be doing anything. Why?
But moving on:

.
.


Q1: How does the number of working hours affect the likelihood of wanting more kids?
.

## trying to use gf_col and make the y axis working hours
fertility_modified %>%
  drop_na(work) %>% 
  gf_col(work ~ morekids) %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 1.A: Those who want More Kids plotted against Working Hours",
          subtitle = "fill = none")









not really the result I was looking for; why is the y axis in a logarithmic scale??


## trying with gf_bar and fill instead
fertility_modified %>% 
  gf_bar(~work,
         fill = ~morekids,
         position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 1.B: Those who want More Kids by Working Hours",
          subtitle = "fill = morekids")








.

Now that’s more like it!!
How would this look like as a line graph?

.

## work vs morekids line graph
fertility_modified %>%
  group_by(work) %>% 
  summarize(morekidsprop = mean(morekids == "yes")) %>% 
  gf_line(morekidsprop ~ work)%>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 1.C:  Proportion of Those who want More Kids by Working Hours",
          subtitle = "line graph")








.


Understandings from the Graphs:

Plot 0.A: In general, there are more people who do not wan;t kids.
Plot 1.B: There seems to be a gradual decline in those who want kids as the work hours per week increase
Plot 1.C: The line graph indicates that there is indeed a decline overall, though it is not a smooth one. When looking at those who work 50 hours a week, the proportion of those who want kids is definitely less than those who work 0 hours a week - However, the same graph indicates that those who work 25 hours a week have a higher proportion of those who want kids in comparison to those who work 23 hours (a lesser amount).

Lets plot other variables to see if there are any stronger patterns


.
.


Q2: Does age affect the likelihood of wanting more kids?
.

## plotting age vs morekids
fertility_modified %>% 
  gf_bar(~age,
         fill = ~morekids,
         position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 2: Those who want More Kids by their age",
          subtitle = "fill = morekids")








.

Wow, interestingly, the proportion of those who want more kids increases steadily with age.

.
.


Q3: How do age and work factor into wanting more kids?
.

## plotting morekids against both age and work
fertility_modified %>%
  gf_bar(~ work | age,
         fill = ~morekids,
         position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 3.A: Those who want More Kids by Age and Working Hours",
          subtitle = "fill = morekids")









The readability is quite low.. what if i filter the ages to look at individually?


## plotting morekids against both age and work - filtered
fertility_modified %>% 
  filter(age == "21")%>%
  gf_bar(~ work | age,
         fill = ~morekids,
         position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 3.B: Those who are 21 vs More Kids and Working Hours",
          subtitle = "fill = morekids")








.


Understandings from the Graphs:

Plot 3.A: Those who are younger seem to have more variation in terms of wanting more kids, that is, it does not seem to be related to their hours of work. Those who are older seem to be of similar opinions across different amounts of work hours, but there is still no established pattern in the relation of the two variables
Plot 3.B: The missing bars indicate that there is no data at that intersection, i.e, there is nobody in this data set who is 21 years old and works 21 hours a week, and so on.



.
.


Q4: Do the gender of the existing children play a part in wanting more kids?
.

## plotting distribution of gender1 and gender 2
fertility_modified %>% 
  gf_bar(~ gender1 | gender2,
         fill = ~morekids,
         position = "stack") %>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 4.A: morekids vs gender",
          subtitle = "fill = morekids")









How can this graph be made more readable?
Lets try.


fertility_modifiedA <- fertility_modified %>%
  dplyr::mutate(
    gender = paste( gender1, gender2, sep = "_"),
    gender = factor(gender,
                    levels = c("male_female", "male_male", "female_male", "female_female", ordered = TRUE ),
                   labels = c("male&female", "male&male","male&female", "female&female", ordered = TRUE )))
 

fertility_modifiedA

# A tibble: 254,654 × 10
   rownames morekids gender1 gender2   age afam  hispanic other  work gender    
      <dbl> <fct>    <fct>   <fct>   <dbl> <fct> <fct>    <fct> <dbl> <fct>     
 1        1 no       male    female     27 no    no       no        0 male&fema…
 2        2 no       female  male       30 no    no       no       30 male&fema…
 3        3 no       male    female     27 no    no       no        0 male&fema…
 4        4 no       male    female     35 yes   no       no        0 male&fema…
 5        5 no       female  female     30 no    no       no       22 female&fe…
 6        6 no       male    female     26 no    no       no       40 male&fema…
 7        7 no       female  male       29 no    no       no        0 male&fema…
 8        8 no       male    male       33 no    no       no       52 male&male 
 9        9 no       female  male       29 no    no       no        0 male&fema…
10       10 no       male    female     27 no    no       no        0 male&fema…
# ℹ 254,644 more rows



fertility_modifiedA%>% 
  gf_bar(~morekids,
         fill = ~gender,
         position = "dodge"
         )%>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 4.B: morekids vs gender",
          subtitle = "fill = gender")









Success!
Now in looking at proportion:


fertility_modifiedA%>% 
  gf_bar(~morekids,
         fill = ~gender,
         position = "fill"
         )%>%
  gf_labs(title = "Plot 4.C: morekids vs gender",
          subtitle = "fill = gender")








.


Understandings from the Graphs:

Plot 4.A: The three combinations of gender are the same relative to each other in both ‘yes’ and ‘no’ sections under wanting more kids. in other words, both sections have participants with male and female children as the largest proportion and participants with two female kids making up the smallest proportion
Plot 4.B: Comparing the proportions, however, can tell us that those who have two kids of the same gender already are more likely (even if by a small margin) to want more kids.



.
.


Q5. What relation (if any) is there between ethnicity and wanting to have more kids?
.

fertility_modified %>% 
  gf_bar(~morekids,
         fill = ~afam,
                              )%>%  
gf_labs(
  title = "Plot 5.A: Counts of those who want More Kids",
  subtitle = "fill = afam")








.

Calculating proportions:

.

fertility_modified %>%
  ##
  group_by(morekids) %>% 
  ##
  summarise(afam_prop = prop(afam), 
            hispanic_prop = prop(hispanic), 
            other_prop = prop(other), 
            majority_prop = sum(prop(afam),prop(hispanic), prop(other))) 

# A tibble: 2 × 5
  morekids afam_prop hispanic_prop other_prop majority_prop
  <fct>        <dbl>         <dbl>      <dbl>         <dbl>
1 no           0.955         0.942      0.951          2.85
2 yes          0.938         0.900      0.931          2.77

  ## the proportions added up become more than 100%??

.

Laying the groundwork, splitting up categories:

.

fertility_modifiedB <- fertility_modified %>%
  group_by(morekids) %>% 
  summarise(
    afam_prop = mean(afam == "yes"),          
    hispanic_prop = mean(hispanic == "yes"),  
    other_prop = mean(other == "yes"),        
    
    ## since the proportions were added together and found to be more than one, identifying the overlapping categories
    
    afam_hispanic = mean(afam == "yes" & hispanic == "yes"),
    afam_other = mean(afam == "yes" & other == "yes"),
    hispanic_other = mean(other == "yes" & hispanic == "yes"),
    ##
    
    only_hispanic = hispanic_prop - sum(hispanic_other, afam_hispanic),
    
    only_afam = afam_prop - sum(afam_hispanic, afam_other),
    
    only_other = other_prop - sum(afam_other, hispanic_other),
    
    majority_prop = mean(afam == "no"& hispanic == "no"& other == "no"),
    minority_prop = sum(only_hispanic, only_afam, only_other, afam_hispanic, afam_other, hispanic_other))  

glimpse(fertility_modifiedB)

Rows: 2
Columns: 12
$ morekids       <fct> no, yes
$ afam_prop      <dbl> 0.04520673, 0.06216980
$ hispanic_prop  <dbl> 0.05824701, 0.10018367
$ other_prop     <dbl> 0.04884558, 0.06854672
$ afam_hispanic  <dbl> 0.0006593044, 0.0009493148
$ afam_other     <dbl> 0, 0
$ hispanic_other <dbl> 0.02232760, 0.04191431
$ only_hispanic  <dbl> 0.03526011, 0.05732004
$ only_afam      <dbl> 0.04454743, 0.06122049
$ only_other     <dbl> 0.02651799, 0.02663241
$ majority_prop  <dbl> 0.8706876, 0.8119634
$ minority_prop  <dbl> 0.1293124, 0.1880366



## Attempting to make my own data set with simply the propotions calculated after summary
fertilitytwo <- readxl::read_excel("../../Data/fertilitytwo.xlsx")

New names:
• `` -> `...1`
• `` -> `...3`
• `` -> `...4`
• `` -> `...5`
• `` -> `...6`
• `` -> `...7`
• `` -> `...8`
• `` -> `...9`
• `` -> `...10`
• `` -> `...11`

fertilitytwo

# A tibble: 3 × 11
  ...1     ethnicity       ...3  ...4  ...5  ...6  ...7  ...8  ...9  ...10 ...11
  <chr>    <chr>           <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr>
1 morekids afam_prop       hisp… othe… afam… afam… hisp… only… only… only… majo…
2 no       4.520673000000… 5.82… 4.88… 6.59… 0     2.23… 3.52… 4.45… 2.65… 0.12…
3 yes      6.216979999999… 0.10… 6.85… 9.49… 0     4.19… 5.73… 6.12… 2.66… 0.18…

## Quickly realising that won't work ;-;

.

Identifying the proportion of the minority, where the majority is defined by those who do not identify as Hispanic, African American or Other.

.

## majority vs minority
fertility_modifiedB %>%
  select(
    morekids, majority_prop, minority_prop
  ) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(majority_prop, minority_prop),
               cols_vary = "fastest",
               names_to = "ethnicity") %>%
  mutate(
          ethnicity = factor(ethnicity,
                              levels = c( "majority_prop", "minority_prop"))
               ) %>% 
  gf_col(value ~ morekids,
         fill = ~ethnicity,
         position = "fill") %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 5.B: Ethnicity: majority and minority vs morekids",
    subtitle = "position = fill"
  )








.

## trying pivot longer 
fertility_modifiedB %>%select(-afam_prop, -hispanic_prop,-other_prop, -majority_prop)%>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(only_hispanic, only_afam, only_other, afam_hispanic, hispanic_other),
               cols_vary = "fastest",
               names_to = "ethnicity") %>% 
  mutate(
                 ethnicity = factor(ethnicity,
                                    levels = c( "only_afam", "afam_hispanic", "only_hispanic", "hispanic_other", "only_other", ordered = TRUE ))
               ) %>% 
  gf_col(value ~ morekids,
         fill = ~ethnicity,
         position = "dodge") %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 5.C: minority ethnicity vs morekids",
    subtitle = "position = dodge"
  )









## PROPORTION
fertility_modifiedB %>%select(-afam_prop, -hispanic_prop,-other_prop, -majority_prop)%>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(only_hispanic, only_afam, only_other, afam_hispanic, hispanic_other),
               cols_vary = "fastest",
               names_to = "ethnicity") %>% mutate(
                 ethnicity = factor(ethnicity,
                                    levels = c( "only_afam", "afam_hispanic", "only_hispanic", "hispanic_other", "only_other", ordered = TRUE ))
               ) %>%
   
  gf_col(value ~ morekids,
         fill = ~ethnicity,
         position = "fill")%>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 5.D: minority ethnicity vs morekids",
    subtitle = "position = fill"
  )








.


Understandings from graphs:

Plot 5.B: Minority ethnicities have a higher proportion of those who want more kids.
Plot 5.C: There is no strong pattern to be concerned with in this plot, as some categories bleed into one another.
Plot 5.D: Those who identify as Hispanic make up for most of those in the minority ethnicity category who want to have more kids, even if by a small margin. The ‘African American Only’ and ‘Other Only’ categories are ever so slightly smaller than their proportion in the ‘no’ more kids category.



.
.

Lets look at every baby name from the US starting all the way from…


…..1880?!?!?

   <dbl> <chr> <chr>     <int>  <dbl>

How many “Aditi”s have existed?

babynames %>% filter(name =="Aditi") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










What about “Adhithi”?

babynames %>% filter(name == "Adhithi") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










“Adithi”?

babynames %>% filter(name == "Adithi") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










or “Adhiti”?

babynames %>% filter(name == "Adhiti") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










In compiling them all into a single graph….

babynames %>% filter(name == "Aditi"|name == "Adhithi"|name == "Adithi"|name == "Adhiti") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










WOAHH!!


Although, my own name has some dissapointing results :(

babynames %>% filter(name == "Vasantha") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










My mother’s name seems to be faring better than mine, across the world..

babynames %>% filter(name == "Meena") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










As are her counterparts!!

babynames %>% filter(name == "Mina") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










And together…

babynames %>% filter(name == "Meena"|name == "Mina") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)










:)

Notes

kbl - from the kableExtra package
makes the data more human readable
head(10) indicates the table will show 10 rows.
‘\n’ acts as line break
Styling (kable_styling):

The table is styled using kable_styling with several bootstrap_options for appearance:

“striped”: Alternating background colors on rows.
“hover”: Highlights rows when hovering over them.
“condensed”: Reduces the row height to make the table more compact.
“responsive”: Ensures the table adjusts to different screen sizes.

full_width = F ensures that the table is not stretched to fill the entire width of the page but rather centered, as specified by position = “center”.



.

title: Day 2: Summaries
section: Data Munging - Mutating data according to your intent:
text:
Data Munging - Mutating data according to your intent:

mpg_modified <- mpg %>%
  dplyr::mutate(
    cyl = as_factor(cyl),
    fl = as_factor(fl),
    drv = as_factor(drv),
    class = as_factor(class),
    trans = as_factor(trans)
  )
glimpse(mpg_modified)

Rows: 234
Columns: 11
$ manufacturer <chr> "audi", "audi", "audi", "audi", "audi", "audi", "audi", "…
$ model        <chr> "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4 quattro", "…
$ displ        <dbl> 1.8, 1.8, 2.0, 2.0, 2.8, 2.8, 3.1, 1.8, 1.8, 2.0, 2.0, 2.…
$ year         <int> 1999, 1999, 2008, 2008, 1999, 1999, 2008, 1999, 1999, 200…
$ cyl          <fct> 4, 4, 4, 4, 6, 6, 6, 4, 4, 4, 4, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 8, 8, …
$ trans        <fct> auto(l5), manual(m5), manual(m6), auto(av), auto(l5), man…
$ drv          <fct> f, f, f, f, f, f, f, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, r, …
$ cty          <int> 18, 21, 20, 21, 16, 18, 18, 18, 16, 20, 19, 15, 17, 17, 1…
$ hwy          <int> 29, 29, 31, 30, 26, 26, 27, 26, 25, 28, 27, 25, 25, 25, 2…
$ fl           <fct> p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, p, r, …
$ class        <fct> compact, compact, compact, compact, compact, compact, com…

Notes

Why make characters into factors? it better organizes the data in hand for plotting.
Sometimes qual data such as year and date are considered as quant data due to their numeric content. These variables can be turned into qual data through munging.


.

Grouping by Qualitative Variables
Highway milage grouped by cylinder type:

mpg_modified %>%
  group_by(cyl) %>%
  summarize(average_hwy = mean(hwy), count = n())

mpg_modified %>%
  group_by(cyl, fl) %>%
  summarize(average_hwy = mean(hwy), count = n())

argument.

title: Day 2: Summaries
text:
Munging Star Trek Data:

## grouping by publisher to understand the average of certain quant variables
startrek_munged <- star_trek_data %>%
  group_by(publisher) %>%
  summarize(avg_nchap = mean(nchap), avg_nw = mean(nword), avg_nchar = mean(nchar), count = n())

## creating a readable table for this summary
startrek_munged %>%
  head(20) %>%
  kbl(
    col.names = c(
      "Publisher","Average\n #of\n Chapters", "Average\n #of\n Words", "Average\n #of\n Characters",
      "Total\n #of\n Books"
    ),
    caption = "Startrek Dataset - Munged"
  ) %>%
  column_spec(1 , border_right = TRUE) %>%
  kable_styling(
    bootstrap_options = c(
      "striped", "hover",
      "condensed", "responsive"
    ),
    full_width = F, position = "center"
  )

bins = the number of classes

the y-axis changes when you change the bins as more the number of class groups, less the number of units within that group > count scale changes

alpha = opacity, valuable for overlapping values
gf_facet_wrap = splits the levels of a variable into their respective graphs
nrow = changes the scale on the y axis
free_y = changes the scales on each graph on gf_facet_wrap

title: Day 4: Quantities
section: Q3: Price Distribution based on Cut, Clarity, Color
text:
Q3: Price Distribution based on Cut, Clarity, Color

can you stack and dodge in histograms?


diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram( ~price,
               fill = ~cut,
               color = "violet",
               alpha = 0.8) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title="Plot 3A: Price distribution based on Cut",
    caption="bins=default=25"
  )









diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram( ~price,
               fill = ~cut,
               position = "dodge",
               color = "violet",
               alpha = 0.8) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title="Plot 3B: Price distribution based on Cut",
    caption="bins = 25, position = dodge"
  )









diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram( ~price,
               fill = ~cut,
               position = "fill",
               color = "violet",
               alpha = 0.8) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title="Plot 3C: Price distribution based on Cut",
    caption="bins = 25, position = fill"
  )









Position ‘dodge’ and ‘stacked’ act as default for gf_facet_wrap. Fill doesn’t make any sense to do as all coloumns would be 1 and filled.


diamonds %>% 
  gf_histogram( ~price,
               fill = ~cut,
               color = "violet",
               alpha = 0.8) %>%
  gf_facet_wrap(~cut) %>% 
  gf_labs(
    title="Plot 3B: Prices by Filled and Facetted by Cut",
    caption="bins = 25"
  )









diamonds %>%
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut, color = "violet", alpha = 0.3) %>%
  gf_facet_wrap(~cut, scales = "free_y", nrow = 2) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3D: Prices Filled and Facetted by Cut",
    subtitle = "Free y-scale, nrow = 2",
    caption = "ggformula"
  ) %>%
  gf_theme(theme(
    axis.text.x =
      element_text(
        angle = 45,
        hjust = 1
      )
  ))









diamonds %>%
  gf_histogram(~price, fill = ~cut, color = "violet", alpha = 0.3) %>%
  gf_facet_wrap(~cut, scales = "free_y", nrow = 5) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Plot 3D: Prices Filled and Facetted by Cut",
    subtitle = "Free y-scale, nrow = 5",
    caption = "ggformula"
  ) %>%
  gf_theme(theme(
    axis.text.x =
      element_text(
        angle = 45,
        hjust = 1
      )
  ))
